Thanks alot for those infos Gordon,

having taking a closer look at the pro=
ject I can see how naive my
approach was. Even though its out of scope for =
my current project it
might still prove usefull to write an EffectiveTLD cl=
ass that can be
used for writing a DomainQueueAssignement policy or a
Cross=
DomainHopDecideRule.
So it might be worth to register this odea as an reque=
st for
enhancement over at JIRA....

Regards
   Olaf Freyer

--- In archive=
-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@...> wrote:
>
> The '5-letter=
-rule' sounds interesting, though I'm sure there are 
> exceptions.
> 
> I =
recently learned of an effort at Mozilla to determine a set of rules 
> for=
 finding the "effective Top Level Domain", essentially what
domain is 
> th=
e fan-out point for delegation/registration by independent 
> administrator=
s. See:
> 
>    http://wiki.mozilla.org/Gecko:Effective_TLD_Service
> 
> If=
 that effort bears fruit, it should provide rules that could be
reused 
> f=
or crawling.
> 
> - Gordon @ IA
> 
> pandae667 wrote:
> > Thanks alot Bjarn=
e for sharing your implementation,
> > 
> > but during further investigatio=
ns towards #HER-1094 I came up with
> > another idea that I think looks pro=
mising (but maybe I don't just see
> > the caveats yet).
> > 
> > The basic=
 problem is "what constitutes a reasonable domain
partitioning" ?
> > Gordo=
n brought up the example of "foo.bar.baz.co.uk" that for sure
> > shouldn't=
 be put in a "co.uk" queue but rather into a "baz.co.uk"
queue.
> > 
> > So=
 my first naive approach would be:
> > if the 2nd level domain consists of =
two or less letters also take the
> > 3rd level domain into account.
> > 
>=
 > But this approach might introduce some unintended side effects -
> > nam=
ely with two letter 2nd level domains under the hood of the general
> > pur=
pose top level domains like .com (for example aa.com).
> > 
> > So the most=
 convenient solution so far seems to me to be something
> > like "the resul=
ting domain should be constructed  by as many domain
> > levels as it takes=
 so that the result contains at least consists of
> > five letters" (notwit=
hstanding http://x.org that takes a special
role...)
> > 
> > examples:
> >=
 foo.bar.baz.example.com =3D> example.com
> > foo.bar.baz.example.co.uk =3D=
> example.co.uk 
> > foo.bar.baz.aa.com > aa.com
> > x.org =3D> x.org
> > 
=
> > To make sure "www.x.org" and "x.org" both enter the same queue
> > stri=
pping any "www[\d]*\." prefix afterwards might seem
reasonable, too.
> > 
>=
 > I consider this idea as a "request for discussion" and hope to get
> > s=
ome helpful comments.
> > 
> > Regards
> >   Olaf Freyer
> > 
> > 
> > --- =

oups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@> wrote:

like a

o
crawl

oth=
erwise I
> >>>>> might DoS customers that use loads of different sub-hostna=
mes for

s yet I'd implement such a policy based upon
> >>>>> SurtAuthorityQueueAssi=
gnmentPolicy.
> >>>> Nothing like that yet exists.
> >>>>

nly an issue only for a certain known set of domains,

> >>>> u=
se the "force-queue-assignment" frontier setting in a domain
> > override 
=
> >>>> to force all URIs in subdomains into the same queue.
> >>>>
> >>>> (=
Specifically: if this setting is non-empty, all URIs to which the 
> >>>> s=
etting applies will have this string, rather than the string
> > given by 
=
> >>>> the assignment-policy, as its queue name.)
> >>>>

 do this would be a valuable contribution. Of
course, for 
> >>>> different=
 top-level-domains the number of domain-segments that
> > reflect 
> >>>> "=
same domain" (in a meaningful shared-ownership sense) varies.
> >>>>
> >>>>=
 - Gordon @ IA
> >>>>

> >>> I do agree that it would=
 be usefull to make such an
AssignementPolicy

eems to me like this isn't an available
option.

ke addElementToDefinition the class would
need to
> >>> extend ComplexType =
- but currently those AssignementPolicies are
based

 class QueueAssignementPolicy.
